descr: Serial No. 907-024 Flat-eight air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, fuel injected, 2196cc, 278hp at 8700 rpm
fact1: A refinement of 6-cyl. 910, this featured better aerodynamics & 8-cyl. engine.
fact2: Long windscreen was inspired by cockpit cover of Mirage fighter jet.
fact3: Coefficient of drag of only 00.27
fact4: Example of obsessive weight reduction: suspension springs have reduced number of coils.
fact5: Driver moved to right side for better car balance & visibility on clockwise road courses.
fact6: First Porsche to exceed 300 kph (186 mph).
fact7: This car won 12 Hours of Sebring in ‘68 by over ten laps over its sister car.
fact8: Car was raced by a rich young Bolivian, Jamie Ortiz-Patiño, in ‘69-‘70 before being tucked away for four decades.

descr: 4 cyl inline pushrod 633cc, 21.2hp @ 4,500 rpm , 1,543 lb, 4 spd manual Trans, 4/5 or 6 pass, Top Speed 57mph
fact1: Current engine - Fiat Abarth A112 engine: 1050 cc, 75 to 80 bhp estimated
fact2: Totally restored in Revs shop
fact3: Produced 1956 to 1969
fact5: 0-50 mph 43.0 seconds in original form
fact6: Top speed 57 mph
fact7: 38 mpg

descr: Serial No. 23-S-28 Four-cylinder in-line engine, dual overhead camshafts
fact1: Diminutive full bodied racer created by Colin Chapman from pieces derived from the single seat Lotus 22.
fact2: First race was in May of 1962 at the Nurburgring Nordschleife.
fact3: With Jim Clark driving the little car soon ran away from the field
fact4: At just over 1000 lb in weight and with great balance it's small 100hp engine provided plenty of power.
fact5: In sight of a sure win the car developed an exhaust leak and crashed but had showed it's merits

descr: Serial No. 593 Two-cylinder 1189cc
fact1: Oldest car in Collection, preserved three generations in original condition.
fact2: Existing wood carriage technology, wagon wheels, steering tiller.
fact3: Set convention of front engine/rear drive layout.
fact4: Panhard-Levassor permitted by Daimler to manufacture Maybach’s gas engine.
fact5: Vaporous fuel with 2-cyl “hot tube” ignition from bunsen burners.
fact6: 3 HP with no throttle, four gears, 10 mph top speed.
fact7: 1895 Paris-Bordeaux-Paris winner - 745 miles in 49 hours.
fact8: 1956 London-Brighton Run - 60 miles (carrying 6 people).

descr: Serial No. 2207 Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 7982 cc, 144 hp at 2500 rpm.
fact1: Example of the way luxury automobiles were sold - custom coach sold separately.
fact2: One of the most advanced cars of its time.
fact3: Pioneered use of aluminum engine parts.
fact4: Chassis shows extremely high quality workmanship and attention to detail.
fact5: Its 6 cylinder engine derived from V8 engine developed by Birgit for WWI aircraft (Spad S.XII and the S.XIII)
fact6: Patented mechanical-servo brakes on all four wheels was a first, licensed to others.

descr: Serial No. 300-128 Flat Six Cylinder, Air Cooled, Single Overhead Cam, 1991cc, 130HP @ 6100RPM's
fact1: “Butzi's” second (and last) design project, as replacement for iconic 356.
fact2: Was Porsche design project 901, but became “911” after Peugeot touted their trademark for production cars of three-number names with a zero in the middle.
fact3: New features: McPherson strut suspension, rack & pinion steering & flat 6-cylinder engine.
fact4: Revs’ car was the 4th of the 1st 200 made, and 1 of 2 sent to US in late ’64 for demonstration/promotion.
fact5: VW dealer in Atlanta bought it in late ’65 & decided to enter it in 24 Hours of Daytona in Feb. of ’66.
fact6: Was a street car, not prepped for racing & had 30,000 miles on it when entered for Daytona.
fact7: Factory Porsche team surprised to see a 911 in the US and entered in the race, even more surprised when it won its class.
fact8: First win for a 911 worldwide.

descr: Serial No. 54148 Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 7272 cc, 95 hp at 1800 rpm.
fact1: Not quite the car Briggs Cunningham thought it was.
fact2: M-B archives helped prove this is a 1921 Mercedes Sport model rather than a ‘23 Targa Florio.
fact3: Mercedes verified serial numbers and racing/exhibition/modification history of the car prior to it coming to the US in 1924, where it acquired a four-seat body.
fact4: Shortly before or after Briggs Cunningham acquired the car in 1947, the body was converted to a two-seat Targa Florio configuration..
fact5: The six-cylinder engine is inspired from an aero design, and cast in 3 blocks of 2 cylinders, with two updraft carburetors.
fact6: The car competed in races and hill climbs, winning an event in Prague in 1922, as per M-B archives.
fact7: Daimler capitalized on racing success of customer/board member Emil Jellinek, who commissioned race cars and named them after beloved daughter, Mercedes.

descr: Serial No. 2110 Four-cylinder in-line engine, 3620 cc (220.9 cubic inches), 64 hp at 2300 rpm.
fact1: Considered to be one of the first sports cars.
fact2: “Boy King” Alfonso’s favored Hispano-Suizas to the point of being a patron and owner of 30.
fact3: This car’s body was replaced to depict one of Alfonso’s favorites, a “voiturette” racer of 1910.
fact4: Fragile wire wheels showed good quality of roads in Europe at the time.
fact5: Restored ‘in-house’ at Revs shop.
fact6: Acetylene headlamps added to this car later; calcium carbide added to water in boxed canister on running board.
fact7: Hispano-Suiza – “Spanish-Swiss”: Company started in Spain later moved to France, with Swiss chief engineer Marc Birkgit.

descr: Serial No. 3030 Eight cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, twin Roots-type superchargers 2991 cc, 360 hp at 6300 rpm
fact1: Unsuccessful Italian response to German Silver Arrows dominance of the late 30s
fact2: 3 made, 2 Campaigned by Lucy O'Reilly Schell race team in the US
fact3: Wilbur Shaw won the 1939 and 1940 Indianapolis 500 in Serial Number 3032
fact4: Our car 3030 won the pikes peak hillclimb in 1946 and 1947 driven by Louis Unser
fact5: The Picture above the car shows our car as it raced at Indy in 1940

descr: Serial No. 718-041 Flat-four air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1697 cc, 170 hp at 7800 rpm
fact1: Further development of suspension & flat-4 cyl. four-cam engine.
fact2: Emphasis on balanced performance over more power.
fact3: 19 RS-60s built.
fact4: Revs’ car won ’60 Targa Florio & close second at Nürburgring 1,000km; This car was borrowed by Porsche to film new Boxster intro, staged on the Targa route.
fact5: RS-60s hampered by new rules for more “road-worthyness” - higher windshield, wipers, luggage space & useless soft-top.
fact6: Rule change influenced by Enzo Ferrari in attempt to thwart Porsches.
fact7: RS-60s won 8 races but lost 1960 manufacturer’s championship to Ferrari in a tie-break.
fact8: This one of several cars in Revs collection driven by Sir Sterling Moss.

descr: Serial No. 718 048: Flat-eight air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1982 cc, 210 hp at 8200 rpm.
fact1: This Chassis is unique served as test bed for development of 8-cylinder F1 engine.
fact2: This was 1 of 2 (of 17 total) that had longer wheelbase for flat 8 engine.
fact3: Bob Holbert received this as replacement for wrecked regular chassis as factory had no other available
fact4: Holbert mounted one of his 4-cam 4's in this longer chassis to complete his championship season
fact5: Bob Holbert won SCCA National Championship in this car ’61-’62.
fact6: Last version of the Porsche aluminum-bodied racers.
fact7: Revs car has the original 8-cylinder factory engine

descr: Serial No. 84461: Flat-four air-cooled engine, rear mounted, twin overhead camshafts, 1587 cc, 160+ hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: By ’54 a third of all 356 model sales were in the US.
fact2: US distributor Max Hoffman convinced Porsche to offer Cabriolet variation that could attract buyers of cars like Jaguar XK120.
fact3: Speedster version launched in ’54, with lower windshield, bucket seats & sliding side curtains; selling for $3,000 it became instant hit, especially in California.
fact4: Stripped and lightened Carrera version created for select amateur racing clients; less than 150 coupes & Speedsters built @ $5,000 ea.
fact5: Fuhrmann 4-cam race engine was Carrera’s main ingredient; 120 mph top speed with 0-60 in 11 seconds.
fact6: This Carrera one of several duplicates campaigned at the same time in SCCA racing in the early 60s by two-time National Champion Bruce Jennings.
fact7: This was Jennings’ medium-speed track version & his favorite; 67 race wins.

descr: Serial No. 70/069: Flat four air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1679 cc, 183 hp.
fact1: Another outcome of Porsche’s preoccupation with F1 in late 50s-early 60s.
fact2: Collaboration with British sports racer company.
fact3: Name comes from French phrase elle va (“she goes”).
fact4: Tubular frame with a fiberglass body.
fact5: At a total of 975 lbs. the lightest car in the collection.
fact6: Based on a Mark VII Elva, rear redesigned to accept the four-cam Fuhrmann Porsche engine.
fact7: Offered in the US as a replacement to the 718 Porsche, 19 made.
fact8: Augie Pabst & Bill Wuesthoff (Revs volunteer) won USRRC Road America 500 a car like ours.

descr: Serial No. 906125: Flat-six air-cooled engine, mounted midship, single overhead camshaft, 1991 cc, 210 hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: “Butzi” ousted from head of design by cousin “Burli” Piëch, who hires 200 engineers to design cars to win LeMans.
fact2: 906 was developed in response to success of Ferrari 196 in ’65.
fact3: Transition to 6-cylinder race engines with Carrera 6.
fact4: Return to tube frame, given reduced homologation requirements & issues repairing 904 box frame.
fact5: 1st Porsche car design to be wind-tunnel tested.
fact6: Last truly road-worthy Porsche racer (though no longer available through dealerships).
fact7: Finished 4th through 7th at ’66 LeMans.

descr: Serial No. 550 032: Flat-four air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1498 cc, 150 hp at 8200 rpm.
fact1: 'One Off' vision of Jean Behra as potential F1 contender under new rules
fact2: Valerio Colotti designed and engineered
fact3: Open wheel, single seat Porsche 718 variant
fact4: Finished 2nd to Sterling Moss at 59 Reims F2 race
fact5: Behra urged Porsche into open wheel racing
fact6: Beat both Porsche and Ferrari F2 cars making Enzo and Ferry upset.
fact7: An early proponent of crash helmets Behra was unfortunately killed at AVUS before the car was fully developed
fact8: In 1962 Dan Gurney won the French GP f1 race in a Porsche F1 car resembling Behra's 1958 F2 machine

descr: Serial No. 1001: Flat-four air-cooled engine, rear-mounted, twin overhead camshafts, 1587 cc, 135 hp at 6500 rpm.
fact1: Porsche now focused on its F1 program & didn’t have time to come up with new sports racer.
fact2: Carlo Abarth called in to run the project in Italy.
fact3: 20 lightweight aluminum bodies styled by Franco Scaglioni & built by Rocco Motto.
fact4: “German engineering with Italian flare.”
fact5: Chopped, shortened & narrowed by 5 inches each way.
fact6: Aerodynamics & lightening allowed top speed of 138 at LeMans, and class win in ’60.
fact7: It took on water when driven in the wet
fact8: Used a Type 692 engine, a larger (1.6 l) and a more developed version of the original 547 four cam family.

descr: Serial No. 917 028 Flat-twelve air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, fuel injected, 4494 cc, 580 hp at 8400 rpm.
fact1: One of the first 917s to race in the US, for Porsche-Audi (PA).
fact2: “Burli” Piëch was persuaded to build this for Can-Am after Volkswagen of America agreed to sponsor program & driver Jo Siffert added his voice.
fact3: Car’s body inspired by the 908/2 “Flunder”.
fact4: Flat 12 engine later turbocharged for up to 1100 hp, to allow Mark Donohue to then dominate Can-Am series by ‘72.
fact5: Despite domination of McLarens (with 10% more hp) in ’69 Can-Am, this car was relatively successful “out of the box” finishing 4th.
fact6: Porsche was finishing development of a 16 Cylinder Can-AM engine when the series rules were changed for 1974 virtually ending the series

descr: Serial No. 9140432542 Flat-six air-cooled engine, mounted midship, single overhead camshaft, 1991 cc, 210 hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: Joint venture between Porsche and Volkswagen, fulfilled long-time commitment Porsche had to develop a VW model that both could market.
fact2: Satisfied needs to replace Porsche’s 4-cyl. 912 and VW’s Karman-Ghia.
fact3: 914 shared body across both companies with brand-specific engines (4-cyl. VW, 6-cyl. Porsche).
fact4: Both versions sold in Europe as VW/Porsches, 4-cyl. at VW dealers, 6-cyl. at Porsche.
fact5: In the US both versions sold as Porsches at Porsche dealers; best seller with 120,000 sold with VW engine, 3,300 with Porsche
fact6: 914/6 GT was race-prepped version; 32 built.
fact7: GT racer debuted at ’70 LeMans, won class and finished 6th overall behind  917s and 2 Ferraris
fact8: Mr. Collier raced this car in the ‘80s.

descr: Serial No. 11899005R Flat-six air-cooled engine, rear mounted, single overhead camshaft, 1991 cc, 210 hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: Racing success of production 911 spurred attempt to produce thinly veiled prototype version & still call it a production 911; sanctioning body didn’t buy it.
fact2: The 23 911Rs already built had to race in non-production classes or as rally cars.
fact3: Up to 300 pounds less weight: fiberglass body panels, plastic windows, plastic door handles.
fact4: 911R was green-lighted only because it appealed to lightness mantra of new head of design, Ferdinand (“Burli”) Piëch, aeronautical engineer by training.
fact5: As a lightweight with 50 more horsepower, the 911R excelled in rally events.
fact6: Rear fenders were slightly flared to fit wider rear tires; became a 911 styling convention.
fact7: Revs’ car won the 6-day Tour de France Rally with Gerard Larrousse (2 Rs!).
fact8: This car participated in the making of Steve McQueen’s racing movie, “LeMans”.

descr: Serial No. 910 007 Flat-six air-cooled engine, single overhead camshaft, fuel injected, 1991 cc, 220 hp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: Relentless quest for weight reduction continues.
fact2: Fiberglass body so thin it seemed translucent; track debris thrown up by tires would perforate wheel wells.
fact3: All factory team cars painted white. Nose color to distinguish team members.
fact4: 30-50 cars produced @ $25,000 ea.
fact5: Only “fresh” factory team cars for important races; once raced they were sold to privateers.
fact6: This car won Nürburgring 1000km race in ’67 for “home bragging rights” & 1st overall win in endurance racing.

descr: Serial No. 908 025: Flat-eight air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, fuel-injected, 2997 cc, 350 hp at 8400 rpm.
fact1: 908 evolved from the 907 to compete in 3-liter class in ’68, lost championship to Ford GT40.
fact2: Carried on in ’69 in wake of development problems with next car (917).
fact3: New 8-cylinder 350hp engine of more simplified design, to last long races.
fact4: Long tapered body had low drag for high-speed but was quite unstable.
fact5: Ailerons added to try to calm car’s tendency to “fly”; actuated by suspension loading.
fact6: This car won the ’69 1000km race at Spa Francorchamps in Belgium & placed 2nd at Monza.
fact7: Sister car lost the ’69 24 Hours of LeMans to a Ford GT40 - by just 400 ft.!

descr: Serial No. 908/03 013: Flat-eight air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, fuel-injected, 2997 cc, 360 hp at 8400 rpm
fact1: Car developed when 917 proved too demanding for tight, twisty courses Targa Florio & Nürburgring.
fact2: Shows Porsche’s dedication to winning - specific cars for specific tracks.
fact3: Weighs 700 lbs less than 917K.
fact4: Only 75 lbs of car’s weight was aluminum frame & plastic body. Extensive use of Titanium.
fact5: Breath-taking power-to-weight ratio.
fact6: This car 1 of the last 2 built, of 13 (in ’71).
fact7: 908/3s won 75% of all races entered; last win in ’80.
fact8: Low polar moment of rotation for optimum handling in corners

descr: Serial No. 904 046 Two liter (1966cc), twin overhead camshaft, Flat four, air cooled engine mounted midship, 180 hp at 7000rpm.
fact1: Successor to 718 RSK — marked Porsche’s return to focus on sports car racing after ill-fated foray in F1.
fact2: New chassis design: Steel perimeter box frame with a fiberglass body bonded on.
fact3: Last Porsche racer you could buy from a dealership, and last to use the Fuhrmann four-cam engine.
fact4: At least 104 produced for homologation with half intended as street cars at a price of $7,000
fact5: In street guise the 904 was called Carrera GTS, given the issue Peugeot had with the zero in the name of the 901 (911) street car.
fact6: Although labeled as a street car, this raced the Targa Florio and the Nurburgring 1000K in 1964.
fact7: Crest logo idea by US distributor Max Hoffman, to convey company’s roots in Stuttgart, a horse-breeding capitol.

descr: Serial No. 904 018 1966cc twin overhead camshaft flat-four, air-cooled engine mounted midship, 180 hp at 7000 rpm
fact1: Competition from Abarth & Alfa Romeo in sports car racing spurred the design.
fact2: Design headed up by Dr. Porsche’s grandson/Ferry’s son “Butzi” at age 28.
fact3: Early vendor-supplied body used crack-prone sprayed chopped fiber technology with significant weight variations.
fact4: Tube frame ditched in favor of a steel perimeter box frame with a fiberglass body bonded to it.
fact5: Last Porsche to use the 4 cylinder four-cam Fuhrmann engine, in racing configuration (the new 6 was not ready in time)
fact6: At least 104 produced, for full homologation; half intended as street cars (though only 38 inches tall) at cost of $7,000.
fact7: This car was Briggs Cunningham’s last race drive (’64 Sebring, 1st in class, 9th overall). First win for a 904 March '64
fact8: 904s placed 1st and 2nd OA in the Targa Florio in april 1964

descr: Serial No. 550A-0139 Flat-four, air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts, 1498 cc, 135 hp at 7200 rpm.
fact1: Evolution from ladder to space frame & pushrod engine to 135hp four-cam Fuhrmann.
fact2: Modified suspension from 550, still with swing axles.
fact3: Could be purchased by amateur racers from dealerships; 40 produced.
fact4: Was a “cradle” for a generation of great drivers.
fact5: 550A-101 Won the 1956 10-lap, 45 miles/lap Targa Florio outright, enhancing “Giant Killer” mystique.
fact6: The 1956 Targa Florio was the first overall victory for Porsche in International competition
fact7: Actor James Dean killed in a 550 Spyder (550-055) (still had ladder frame).

descr: Serial No. 225007A: Eight-cylinder L-head in-line engine, nine main bearings, 384 cubic inches, 106 hp at 3200 rpm.
fact1: An aberration from a company known for big touring cars and stately convertibles
fact2: The brainchild of Packard chief engineer Jesse Vincent, who was something of a “speed freak”.
fact3: This was one of 4 prototype test mules built to establish what would become the 626 Speedster (1929-30).
fact4: In-line 8 cyl., 106 hp engine set in shortened chassis.
fact5: Vincent took Yale-bound Briggs Cunningham for a 100 mph test drive that sold BSC.
fact6: After buying car, BSC replaced 4-seat body with recreation of another Speedster prototype.
fact7: Car was tested extensively on Yale dynamometer for the 2 years BSC was an engineering student there.

descr: Serial No. 1858 4-cyl, 3619 cc, 40-45 HP, HP to WT Ratio: 39.2, Weight: 1764 pounds
fact1: Perfect example of a preservation car.
fact2: In the same Spanish family for 80 years.
fact3: Original, unrestored, running condition.
fact4: Gauges and electric system were only additions to this car.
fact5: One of seven known to exist.
fact6: Swiss Marc Birkgit designed “Hissos” from 1905 to ‘38.
fact7: Company built 50,000 WWI aircraft engines for Allies.

descr: Serial No. 1449 Four-cylinder in-line engine, T-head, 597 cubic inches, 60 hp at 1200 rpm.
fact1: “American Mercedes” - New York investors created car because high tariffs kept them from importing Daimlers.
fact2: Was a high status, expensive, extremely well built auto.
fact3: NYC built, then New Brunswick, NJ - 250 units.
fact4: Brooklyn track record; 1,177 miles in 24 hours.
fact5: Barron Collier sold this car to Briggs Cunningham
fact6: One of the fastest cars of its time - top speed in excess of 75 mph.
fact7: Like the Mercer, this was an All-American racer built for speed.

descr: Serial No. 3003 (356/2 055) Flat-four, air-cooled pushrod VW-type engine, rear-mounted, Porsche–designed cylinder heads, 1498 cc, 72 hp at 5000 rpm.
fact1: Design started by son “Ferry” in 1947 while Dr. Ferdinand Porsche still imprisoned.
fact2: First 50 356s were built 1948-49 in converted Austrian sawmill, bodies of hand-hammered aluminum.
fact3: Production moved to Stuttgart in rented Reutter coachworks space in 1950.
fact4: Stuttgart produced mostly steel bodied cars but also a few SL (super light) aluminum bodied racing 356s as well.
fact5: Gmünd 356 became first Porsche entered at LeMans (1951); wins class & 19th overall.
fact6: This car recently received a multi-year restoration
fact7: Our SL restored in Livery of Liege-Rome-Liege rally, in which it won it's class and 3rd overall
fact8: In September 1951 our car ran the Montlhery track for 72 hr averaging 94.66 mph, setting a record.

descr: Serial No. 4959 Eight‐cylinder in‐line engine, single overhead camshaft, three valves per cylinder (two inlet, one outlet), Roots type supercharger 2261 cc (138 cubic inches), 140 hp at 5000 rpm.
fact1: Built as 1 of three for Targa Florio 1930
fact2: Placed 2nd in the 1930 race with Louis Chiron as driver
fact3: Raced in Pau region of France pre-WWII
fact4: Discovered in the UK in 2006 as a 'barn find'
fact5: Type 35 credited with over 2000 race wins in it's career

descr: Modified Flat four 2.6 Liter Type 4, 207 Hp, 190+ lb/ft torque
fact1: Ferdinand Porsche won 1934 design competition to create a “People’s Car” for Hitler’s Third Reich (project 60).
fact2: Hitler named it the Kraft-durch-Freude-Wagen  ('Strength Through Joy Car'), or KdF-Wagen.
fact3: Original 25 HP Beetle was designed for a top speed of around 62 mph. Now 0-60 5.0 sec top speed 120 mph
fact4: Limited production launched in ‘38 but halted with the start of WWII after a few hundred produced.
fact5: Damaged Wolfsburg factory seized after the war and was offered to other carmakers - no takers.
fact6: British Major Ivan Hirst started up production of the Beetle to get people working again.
fact7: The car that 'no one wanted' ended up its 65-year production run with nearly 22 million built.
fact8: Our car Restored as 'Hot Rod'. 207 HP engine vs. original 36 HP motor, Porsche suspension & brakes, and aluminum body panels.

descr: Serial No. OE 305 Four-cylinder in-line pushrod engine, 4224 cc, 120+ hp at 3500 rpm.
fact1: This car was one of the last built of this model, spanning 596 cars over 14 years.
fact2: Originally owned by a young Henry B. DuPont.
fact3: Acquired after WWII by Col. George Felton.
fact4: Felton beefed up the engine, brakes & suspension, replaced the running boards with cycle fenders.
fact5: He also stripped the paint down to polished aluminum (hence “Quicksilver”)
fact6: Raced in first post-WWII road race at Watkins Glen GP in 1948 (DNF); 9th in ‘49 (as pictured).
fact7: Tonneau cover used to ‘streamline” the car.

descr: Serial No. E311 Four-cylinder in-line side valve engine, 4526 cc, 90 hp at 2800 rpm.
fact1: Built as a touring auto, considered the first British sports car.
fact2: Developed in just 71 days.
fact3: Car was a competitor of Bentley and Rolls Royce.
fact4: Popular “gentleman’s hill-climb car”.
fact5: Vauxhall warranted that a stripped down Type E could reach 100 mph.
fact6: Model referred to 30 “RAC rated” HP & 98 mm piston bore.
fact7: Despite early use of front-wheel (drum) brakes, the car was woeful to stop.
fact8: Velox: Latin for “swift or fleet”.

descr: Serial No. 4003 HG Six-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, seven main bearings, dry sump lubrication, 2916 cc, 90 hp at 3800 rpm.
fact1: First dual overhead cam engine in a production car.
fact2: Exotic race car engine in a street car.
fact3: $6,750 cost & complex engineering during depression limited customer pool - only 315 built.
fact4: Dry-sump lubrication a novel engine feature.
fact5: Conceived to challenge Bentley dominance.
fact6: Motor built in ‘26, chassis ‘27, car assembled in ‘28 but not sold until early ‘29.
fact7: Land speed record (203.793 mph) set by Henry Seagrave in a Sunbeam powered two-engine streamliner version, March 29, 1927

descr: Serial No. 9043 L-head four-cylinder in-line engine, 176.7 cubic inches, 22 hp at 1600 rpm.
fact1: The car that brought auto travel to the masses. Total of over 15 million built 1908-1927.
fact2: By the 20s half the cars in the world were Model Ts.
fact3: Four-cylinder mono block engine made use of detachable cylinder head.
fact4: Hand-built 1909-1913, with initial price of $850.
fact5: After assembly line method adopted in 1914, cost eventually dropped to $285.
fact6: Assembly line build time of 90 minutes/car meant black was only color that dried fast enough.
fact7: Produced with interchangeable parts - led to “shade tree” home mechanic.
fact8: Ford touted left-hand drive as feature for passenger (often a lady) to step out onto curb side.

descr: Serial No. 3317: Two-cylinder, four-stroke, opposed engine. 2690 cc, 10 hp at 920 rpm
fact1: Benz largest car maker in world then - 603 produced in 1900.
fact2: This 10 HP, 2-cyl. boxer was popular model.
fact3: “Back to back” layout obsolete in 1901.
fact4: Benz resisted change - felt 18 mph sufficient (still faster than horse drawn wagon).
fact5: This car displayed at 50th anniversary of the auto in Germany in 1936.
fact6: Car then survived WWII fire bombing of Dresden stored in a salt mine.
fact7: Car displayed in East German museum until fall of Wall, then completely restored.

descr: Serial No. Z30003: Four-cylinder engine, 9236cc (573 cubic inches), magneto ignition. 60 hp at 1400 rpm.
fact1: This car 75 Mph. Sister car set Land speed record at 76.08 MPH in '02
fact2: Wooden frame, Chain Drive, Pneumatic shock absorbers
fact3: Driver and Mechanic needed to keep car running and maintained during race
fact4: 'Total Loss' lubrication system and Fuel pumped manually.
fact5: Tube tires are natural rubber with cotton cord, very fragile prone to failure
fact6: No front brakes, braking ineffective

descr: Serial No. 1406V: Six-cylinder in-line engine, L-head, 5900cc, 28 hp, HP to WT Ratio: 136.75
fact1: Example of early “prestige” motorcar, favored by Heads of State (e.g. Czar Nicholas, King Alphonso XIII).
fact2: Built by French marine boiler company, with body by Mulliners Ltd.UK
fact3: Adopted the fully pressurized oil system that Bellville patented in 1897.
fact4: Could approach 60 mph and maintain it indefinitely.
fact5: Some cars documented to have gone 200,000 miles between motor overhauls.

descr: Serial No. 48: Four cylinder in-line engine, overhead valves pushrod actuated, 12.5 liters (775 cubic inches), 100bhp.
fact1: 1908 was Mors last significant racing effort
fact2: Powerful and fast they were favored by wealthy racers including Charles Rolls and william Vanderbuilt
fact3: Andre Citroen becomes chairman after company reorganization in 1908
fact4: Built quickly they were not very reliable their best finish was 16th in the French GP
fact5: Citroen phases out the brand in the 20s
fact6: Typical of large Displacement engines prior to Peugeot engine design breakthroughin 1913

descr: Serial No. 764: Four-cylinder in-line T-head engine, 300 cubic inches, 58 hp at 1700 rpm.
fact1: Considered to be America’s first sports car.
fact2: A true racer ... minimalist to an extreme.
fact3: Once had accessory “monocle windshield” & spotlight.
fact4: In 1911 Mercer won 5 of 6 major races entered.
fact5: Arch-rival of Stutz Bearcat.
fact6: Muscular when compared to the Hispano–Suiza T-15
fact7: Sturdy caisson wheels necessary to survive the bad American roads of the time
fact8: Capable of top speed of at least 75 mph, with barely adequate brakes.

descr: Serial No. Four-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder, 2980 cc (183 cubic inches), 90 hp at 2900 rpm.
fact1: Engineers Ernest Henry and 'Les Charlatans' develop first DOHC engine architecture
fact2: 3 liter Peugeot engine developed 90hp vs 100 hp for the 12 liter 1908 Mors
fact3: At 1914 Indy 500 led 77 laps before finishing 2nd to Delage with engine twice as large
fact4: US reporters nicknamed the car Baby (Le Bebe) because of it's size and light weight
fact5: Engine became the inspiration for new designs by many others including Miller and Bugatti

descr: Serial No. B.N.209 M.N.5: Four-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 4483cc(273.7 cubic inches), 115 HP at 2800 rpm
fact1: Mercedes won French Grand Prix in 1914 1-2-3. Our car is one of two to survive (5 originals)
fact2: Advanced OHV design adapted from Aero engines beat twin cam Peugeots
fact3: Pre-race planning and mods to suit conditions as well as organized 'pit crew' helped them win
fact4: First team to use Pit Signals to driver, Competitors considered this 'unsporting'
fact5: 250k spectators for the race. Weeks later WWI began
fact6: Our car and the other survivor (number 28 winner) toured Europe in 2014 to reprise 1914 victory
fact7: Our car was test and practice car (bis means spare or alternate)

descr: Serial No. 65RB: Six-cylinder in-line engine, 7428 cc (453 cu.in.), 40/50 HP (48.6 R.A.C.), HP to WT Ratio: 88.85
fact1: Set standard for automotive reliability, refinement & excellence.
fact2: Nearly 8,000 built over 20 year run.
fact3: Car catered to the extremely wealthy, European royalty & the “new royalty” in the US.
fact4: Colonial model cost $7,000 for chassis, with body by Kellner (Paris) at close to $10,000.
fact5: As per Rolls-Royce advertising: “The quality will remain long after the price is forgotten.”
fact6: This car was built on the London-Edinburgh sporting chassis with higher performance.
fact7: Car’s uncanny silence earned it the name ”The Silver Ghost”.
fact8: This Rolls has dual ignitions: one distributor-based for starting, the other magneto-based for running.

descr: Serial No. 13251: Six-cylinder in-line engine, T-head, dual valves, 477 cubic inches, 48 rated hp.
fact1: American prestige manufacturer - one of the 'Three Ps' (with Packard & Peerless)
fact2: A status symbol with understated elegance.
fact3: A favorite car for Presidents from Taft to Hoover.
fact4: Headlamps set into fenders was a styling hallmark.
fact5: Extensive use of aluminum body panels.
fact6: Engine electric self-starter was an innovation. (Invented by Charles Kettering founder of Delco - Dayton Engineering Laboratories Co.)
fact7: Engine compartment featured a built-in air compressor.

descr: Serial No. 1003: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder, 4816 cc, 140 hp at 3000 rpm.
fact1: Car designed by Ernest Henry with an 8 cylinder engine similar in design to 1913 Peugeot
fact2: The goal was to burnish the Ballot brand with a sucessful racing effort
fact3: Rene' Thomas was named team manager and the 1919 Indy project proceeded in secret
fact4: In just over 100 days the first car was completed (4 cars were sent to Indy)
fact5: Underslung front suspension made the car low and sleek, It qualified 1st at 104.7 mph, the first pole sitter over 100
fact6: Our car #31 finished 11th at Indy in spite of the fact that tire/wheel choice had caused other teammates to crash.
fact7: Our car, originally thought to be number 33 (1001), was actually found to be number 31 (1003) during restoration'
fact8: During restoration it was repainted using original formula paint applied with a brush as it was done in 1919.

descr: Serial No. V2911: Eight-cylinder, 90 degree vee engine, L-head 441.7 cubic inches, 95 hp at 2400 rpm. HP to WT Ratio: 40.78
fact1: Beautiful speedster built in Rochester, NY by a company better known for its limousines and hearses.
fact2: This car was used to set speed records as a way of marketing the company's prowess.
fact3: Indy 500-winner Ralph DePalma set 3 speed records on board track in Sheepshead Bay, NY.
fact4: Averaged 98 mph in a 10 mile sprint, and also set a record driving back to Rochester after the time trials.
fact5: Boasted the largest V8 at that time (441.7 cu/in) and muffler cut-outs on floorboard to by-pass exhaust for more power.
fact6: Cunningham cars (no relation to Briggs) were regarded as the 'American Rolls Royce', built for the rich and famous.
fact7: Clients included Mary Pickford, Harold Lloyd, Hoot Gibson, Fatty Arbuckle, Cecil B. DeMille, William Randolph Hearst, Marshall Field

descr: Serial No.?: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, supercharged
fact1: Harry Miller machinist and carburetor builder asked to work on Peugeot and uses design for his engine
fact2: Uses centrifugal supercharger to add power
fact3: Miller engines dominate Indy. Lap record at Indy held for 8 Years
fact4: Miller sells business to Offenhauser who continues to develop engine and continues Indy domination
fact5: Meyer-Drake next to develop the design into the 70s Turbo era.
fact6: Our car is a board track version with centrifugal supercharger

descr: Serial No. NR 516: Four-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, four valves per cylinder, 2996 cc, 80-82 hp at 3500 rpm.
fact1: Bentley would build production race cars for anyone who could afford them.
fact2: Underpinnings of this car were from the car that won 1924 LeMans.
fact3: Bentley guaranteed SS would achieve 100 mph. 5 years warranty unless the car was raced then only a one-year guarantee.
fact4: Wealthy London butcher who owned this car ordered it with custom nautical-theme coach from Serbico coachbuilders.
fact5: True “speedster” design from rounded front radiator, marine wind screen, use wood trim, boat-tail rear and wind-swept fenders.
fact6: Bentley also won Le Mans in 1927 with a 3.0 liter, 1928 with a 4.5 liter and 1929 and 1930 with a 6.5 liter

descr: Serial No. 21642: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder. Roots-type supercharger, 1486 cc, 170 bhp at 8000 rpm.
fact1: 1926 version was probematic. Configuration of Exhaust manifold and supercharger location 'baked' drivers
fact2: 1927 version moved exhaust away from driver and supercharger relocated to front of engine solved problems
fact3: Offset engine allowed low sleek design. Delage was virtually unbeatable in 1927
fact4: Robert Benoist won 5 of 7 races in 1927 and Delage placed 1,2,3 in both French and British GPs that year.
fact5: Excellent braking due to use of Hispano-Suiza licensed power brake design
fact6: 'wings' behind front wheels deflect road debris without the drag of fenders
fact7: Our car competed in the first Grand Prix of Monaco April 14 1929

descr: Serial No. 17181: Narrow angle (14 degree) V4 engine, two valves per cylinder, single overhead camshaft 2370 cc, 59 hp at 3250 rpm
fact1: A rough sea crossing inspired Vincenzo Lancia to emulate the stressed panel hull of ships for automobiles.
fact2: This created the first “unibody” car chassis, a radical departure from conventional ladder-frame construction of the day.
fact3: Allowed lower passenger compartment & resulting driveshaft tunnel gave even more rigidity.
fact4: Lighter weight meant less dependence on large motor for performance.
fact5: First production use of V-4 engine (single block and cylinder head).
fact6: Sliding pillar independent front suspension also a first in a production car.
fact7: Lancia named cars after sequential Greek letters until 1937.

descr: Serial No. 11739: Six-cylinder in-line overhead camshaft engine, 7982 cc, 194 bhp at 3000 rpm.
fact1: A grand and elegant touring car conveying luxury, prestige, and exclusivity.
fact2: Meticulous engineering, aircraft-based engine.
fact3: Jewel-like seven-main-bearing crankshaft machined from a 770 pound billet.
fact4: Many thought “Hissos” were superior to Rolls-Royce.
fact5: All bodies were custom-built coachwork.
fact6: “Stork” mascot - honor from WWI French squadron emblem (that used H-S aero engines).
fact7: Boat tail theme evident in execution of rear fnder wings and body rear, as if cutting through water.; windscreen suggestive of a speedboat windscreen.
fact8: Angled two piece windscreen suggestive of a speedboats of the time.

descr: Serial No. B8612-BA29C: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 298 cubic inches, 115 hp at 3600 rpm. HP to WT Ratio: 38.94
fact1: A US supercar that challenged Europe’s elite manufacturers, e.g. Bentley, Hispano-Suiza.
fact2: Successor to the earlier Bearcat ... faster, lighter and lower.
fact3: Harry C. Stutz credited with the development of the 'under-slung chassis' for the Amercan Motor Car company early in his carreer
fact4: Strong overhead cam straight 8 engine, developed with testing at Indianapolis Motor Speedway.
fact5: Match race lost to Hispano-Suiza led to 1928 Le Mans entry - by Hispano-Suiza’s Charles Weymann!
fact6: Placed 2nd in 1928 Le Mans (last US car there until Cunningham’s Cadillacs).
fact7: 106 mph run at 1928 Daytona Speedweek made Black Hawk the fastest US production car.

descr: Serial No. 36242: Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, Roots-type supercharger, 7059 cc, 140 hp at 3200 rpm (200 hp with blower engaged).
fact1: One of the most powerful sports cars of its time.
fact2: Last design project by Dr. Ferdinand Porsche before he left MB to start his own design firm.
fact3: SSK - Super Sport Kurz, German for 'Super Sport Short'.
fact4: Meant for short, twisty circuits and hill climbs
fact5: Use of supercharger gave in excess of 200 hp when engaged.
fact6: This car owned by Dorothy Paget, eccentric heiress to the American Whitney fortune and 2nd richest person in England at the time.
fact7: Only 31 built, influenced future designs.

descr: Serial No. 2349: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder, 420 cubic inches, 265 hp at 4200 rpm.
fact1: E.L. Cord acquired Duesenberg in 1926; retained Fred & Augie to create the pinnacle of US custom automobiles.
fact2: Ultimate car for those seeking to be seen.
fact3: Finished cars cost as much as $25,000 (over $375,000 in 2019 dollars).
fact4: 265 HP motor was most powerful production engine in the world; top speed of 116 mph.
fact5: This car’s custom body by LeBaron of Detroit features Dual Cowl Phaeton style
fact6: “Le Baron Sweep” and “Bowtie” front bumper are styling hallmarks
fact7: Racing Duesenbergs won the French Grand Prix and the Indianapolis 500 in the 20s.

descr: Serial No. Serial No. YX5117, Engine No. YX5120: Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, four valves per cylinder, three SU carburetors, 7983 cc (487.12 cubic inches), 250 hp at 3500 rpm.
fact1: This model was Bentley's last effort to stay financially solvent.
fact2: Most advanced Bentley design to date.
fact3: Soon after, Bentley closed, went into receivership & eventually became a part of Rolls-Royce.
fact4: Ironically, this model was an effort to directly challenge Rolls-Royce.
fact5: Has a huge 144” wheelbase for a 2-seater auto - and this was a shortened version.
fact6: $9,000 chassis, final model built as limousine.

descr: Serial No. 55211: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, Roots-type supercharger, 2970 cc, 135 hp at 5500 rpm.
fact1: Road going version of Grand Prix racer.
fact2: Exquisite body designed by Ettore Bugatti’s son, Jean (at age 22).
fact3: Supercharged Grand Prix engine made it ideal for sports racing.
fact4: 99 mph in ¼  mile, 60 mph under 13 sec.
fact5: 38 built in France between 1932 – ‘35.
fact6: Aesthetic details: brightwork (e.g. swooping axle), paint scheme, cast aluminum spoked wheels.
fact7: Tony Hogg, Road and Track editor said, 'The definition of what defines a sports car is the Bugatti'.
fact8: Horseshoe grill actually meant to resemble part of a chair as an homage to Ettore’s father, a renowned furniture craftsman.

descr: Serial No. 1930 Engine / 1933 Chassis Engine No. M-1011: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder, Centrifugal supercharger with intercooler manifold, 168.7 cubic inches, 200 + hp
fact1: Underwent several iterations in it's lifetime: two seat and single seat versions
fact2: 1931 Indy 500 2nd place finisher, 'Fabulous' Fred Frame driver 109.273 mph qualifying speed
fact3: Unique Sidewinder centrifugal supercharger
fact4: Maserati brakes operated by outside handbrake lever.
fact5: Ford transmission, Bugatti rear end, Dry sump oiling with 4 gal reservoir
fact6: One time 'Dutchess' Dorothy Gruman team car

descr: Serial No. 2069-5491: Twelve-cylinder, 67 degree vee engine, 445.47 cubic inches, 160 hp at 3200 rpm.
fact1: More understated luxury than the Duesenberg.
fact2: Appealed to corporate & government leaders.
fact3: Custom coach-built body by Dietrich of Detroit
fact4: Dual cowl windshield for rear seat passengers was true luxury feature. Rolls down behind front seat.
fact5: Survived the Depression by appealing to a wider audience.
fact6: V12 engine was one way to differentiate in a limited market.
fact7: Smoothness and power of the Packard V12 inspired Enzo Ferrari to use V12s in his early Ferraris

descr: Serial No. 2311241: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, Roots-type supercharger, 2336 cc, 142 hp at 5000 rpm.
fact1: Pre-eminent Italian sports car of the ‘30s.
fact2: A car a privateer could purchase and enjoy on public roads and also race successfully.
fact3: 8C 2300s won four consecutive Le Mans (1931-34).
fact4: Also dominated Mille Miglia & Targa Florio.
fact5: Superb handling, flexible manners.
fact6: 0 to 60 mph in under 10 seconds from 8-cyl. supercharged engine.
fact7: Corto = short wheelbase.

descr: Serial No. K3025: Six-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, 1086 cc, up to 120+ bhp at 6500 rpm. Roots-type Marshall supercharger. Four-speed E.N.V. preselector gearbox.
fact1: This car began to challenge other European sports racers in races such as Mille Miglia.
fact2: Won class and team prize at '33 Mille Miglia, and placed 4th at ‘34 LeMans.
fact3: Nuvolari won Tourist Trophy with one.
fact4: This was the largest of three racing models from MG
fact5: Around 35 built, priced at £795 - could be ordered from catalogue or off showroom floor.
fact6: Novel pre-selector gear shift mechanism allowed advance selection-then-activation by pedal when needed, in place of clutch.

descr: Serial No. 1915189: Eight-cylinder L-head in-line front mounted engine, 323.5 cubic inches (5301 cc), 128 hp at 3400 rpm
fact1: Effort by young Chrysler company to come up with an innovation in aerodynamics and construction.
fact2: Orville Wright one of several engineers involved in testing aerodynamic auto shapes.
fact3: Flowing front end styling came from wind tunnel testing of cars of the day running backwards.
fact4: Cage construction and use of single piece of stressed steel led to car 4-times more rigid than any other.
fact5: Moving engine forward allowed back seat ahead of real axle, giving more room in passenger compartment & evening out weight of car.
fact6: Although an engineering marvel, its unconventional design and early quality issues turned off the public.
fact7: Chrysler hoped to sell 35,000 a year, but sold only a third of that in ‘34.
fact8: Continued slumping sales led to the plug being pulled in ‘37. Just 212 of these CV Coupes were built, only a few survive.

descr: Serial No. 48563: Six-cylinder in-line pushrod engine
fact1: High water mark of pre-WWII styling.
fact2: Built as a show car, it starred at the 1937 Paris Auto Show with its Figoni & Falaschi body.
fact3: Car appears to be floating on air with its grandeur, fluid design & aerodynamics.
fact4: Leather interior by Hermès.
fact5: Despite its Art Deco style, the DNA of the 1938 LeMans-winning Delahaye is beneath.
fact6: Four patented features, unique fenders.
fact7: Grill, bumpers changed after a year (see photos).
fact8: Reproduced iridescent paint & color matches original “fish scale” paint.

descr: Serial No. 412036: Eight-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, supercharged, 2905 cc, 180 bhp at 5200 rpm.
fact1: The most elegant high performance car of era.
fact2: Stylish body by Touring of Milan in Superlegerra (super light) style.
fact3: Derived from the 2900 supercharged Grand Prix car.
fact4: Supercharged, twin cam, 8 cylinder engine.
fact5: Less than 40 built in 1937-‘39, in short and long chassis configurations.
fact6: Examples finished 1-2-3 in '36 Mille Miglia, and one won the first running of Watkins Glen in 1948
fact7: This car also won the Mille Miglia - in 1947!; 4th Mille Miglia win for the model.

descr: Serial No. Serial No. 85246: Six-cylinder in-line engine, vee-type overhead valves, aluminum cylinder head combining hemispherical combustion chambers with side camshaft, 1971 cc, 80 hp at 5000 rpm.
fact1: Vehicle that put young BMW company “on the map” as a sports car manufacturer.
fact2: Car’s flowing, integrated roadster look was years ahead of its time.
fact3: Far exceeded performance expectations for a relatively small engine - 100 mph from 80 hp.
fact4: An example won ’40 Mille Miglia, among many other European races.
fact5: 464 built, virtually all of them were raced at one time or another.
fact6: Hugely successful in competition and hill climbs.
fact7: Innovative Hemi-head engine used by Bristol cars in UK after WWII

descr: Serial No. 33409938: Eight-cylinder in-line overhead valve engine, 320 inches (5245 cc).
fact1: Briggs Cunningham’s first attempt at building a sports car, albeit a “hot rod”.
fact2: “Unholy marriage” of a 1939 Buick Century V8 & chassis & Mercedes SSK body.
fact3: C. Miles and Sam Collier raced this in early US sports car ARCA events prior to WWII.
fact4: Post-war the car ran at 1948 & ‘49 Watkins Glen Grand Prix - finished 2nd & 3rd respectively.
fact5: Portent of Cunningham’s later efforts in designing and building race cars.
fact6: This car could be considered part of the foundation of modern sports car racing in the US.

descr: Serial No. Serial No. 15: Twelve cylinders in vee formation, double overhead camshafts, two Roots-type superchargers 2962cc, 483 hp at 7800 rpm
fact1: Apex of pre-WWII German racing technology, last Silver Arrow raced pre-war
fact2: 2nd place finish in final race. Led from start but spun on last lap
fact3: 200mph capable, could spin tires in any gear.
fact4: Driver VonBrauchitsch beaten by Auto Union driven by Tazio Nuvolari
fact5: Fuel exotic mixture, Methyl Alcohol, Acetone, Sulfuric Ether & Nitro Benzine
fact6: Discovered behind the 'Iron Curtain' in the 50s

descr: Serial No. 016-I: Twelve-cylinder, 60 degree vee engine, single overhead camshaft, 1992 cc, 130 hp at 7000 rpm (140 hp with higher compression and alcohol fuel).
fact1: 166 Inter Spyder Corsa was Ferrari’s first customer model, for wealthy clients who wanted to go racing.
fact2: “Inter” designation for ability to run in F2 (w/o fenders & lights) or sports category (with).
fact3: V-12 design inspired by 12-cyl. Packard; each piston the size of a tomato paste can.
fact4: 016-I was 8th of nine built; driven as semi-works car by Luigi Chinetti in 1948.
fact5: BSC bought 016-I from Luigi Chinetti in lieu of a Jaguar XJ120. Arrived in US June 5th 1949.
fact6: First Ferrari racer in US & 1st US Ferrari race win, with BSC at Suffolk Co. Airport in ‘50.
fact7: 2nd in ‘49 Watkins Glen GP, leading on first lap of ‘50 race with Sam Collier when he crashed & was killed.
fact8: Sam Collier 6 Hour Memorial held at Sebring Dec. 31 ‘50 as track’s first race - became 12 Hours of Sebring in ‘52.

descr: Serial No. 506111399: Eight-cylinder, 90 degree vee engine, overhead valves, 331 cubic inches, 160 hp at 3800 rpm.
fact1: Briggs Cunningham's first foray at Le Mans - a test to see how well an American car could manage in a 24-hour road race.
fact2: Cunningham decided to run American cars with American drivers.
fact3: Driving this car assigned to his friends from Yale and ARCA, C. Miles & Sam Collier.
fact4: Series 61 was Cadillac’s smallest and lightest model (at 3,900 lbs!) with America's best Engine (Cadillac V8.)
fact5: Engine, Brakes, Wheels, modified, but otherwise car was bone stock - even AM radio kept in.
fact6: Carried “White with Blue” American colors.
fact7: Nicknamed “Petit Pataud” (“Clumsy Pup”)
fact8: Came in tenth overall, just ahead of Briggs Cunningham & Phil Waters in other Cadillac (le Monstre).

descr: Serial No. 506112964: Eight-cylinder, 90 degree vee engine, overhead valves, 331 cubic inches, 160 hp at 3800 rpm.
fact1: Rules permitted re-bodying of standard automobiles.
fact2: Grumman Aircraft engineers assist after-hours in coming up with lighter, wind tunnel-tested aerodynamic body over stock Cadillac chassis.
fact3: Actually shorter, lower & narrower than “Petit Pataud” & 13 mph faster (130 mph top speed).
fact4: Dubbed “Le Monstre” by the French.
fact5: Aerodynamic panels over wheels meant insufficient cooling for already marginal drum brakes.
fact6: Brakes faded early in the race & car went into sand bank; took 2 hours to dig out and get going, with damaged transmission.
fact7: Cunningham & co-driver Phil Waters finished 11th, just behind the Collier brothers in the stock Cadillac.

descr: Serial No. 131 SC: Four-cylinder in-line pushrod engine, 1090 cc, 60 hp at 5500 rpm.
fact1: Piero Dusio’s Consorzio Industriale Sportivo Italia (CISItalia) made sporting goods pre-WWII & Italian Army uniforms during the War.
fact2: Dusio’s prior experience racing led to decision to build cars after WWII.
fact3: First made Fiat-parts F2 cars, then pulled in Ferry Porsche (via Carlo Abarth) to help design F1 car (Porsche 360).
fact4: Dusio also paid for release of Dr. Porsche & Anton Piech (deducted from Porsche 360 job).
fact5: At same time, Dusio decided to build sports coupe based on F2 car, with ex-Fiat engineer.
fact6: Dusio friend Battista “Pinin” Farina created what became template for GT cars of the 50s, with flowing single envelope design.
fact7: NYC’s Museum of Modern Art displayed as one of the ten most beautiful cars ever made.
fact8: Just over 100 202SCs built before company, dragged down by F1 project, moved to Argentina to build industrial equipment.

descr: Serial No. 5101: Cadillac eight-cylinder, 90 degree vee engine, overhead valves, 331 cubic inches, 220 hp.
fact1: Start of BSC’s effort to build his own race cars.
fact2: Styling progenitor of later two-seat, V-8 powered American sports cars (e.g. Cobra, early ‘Vette).
fact3: Built at former Frick-Tappet machine shop in West Palm Beach.
fact4: Aluminum body on massive steel tube frame w/ 4 tube shocks & 4 rotary shocks.
fact5: “Hot rod” with assortment of suspension & other parts pulled from various cars.
fact6: Modified 331 cu. in. OHV Cadillac V8.
fact7: After this, Cadillac refused to supply engines; BSC Yale friend was son of Chrysler Exec. link for switch to Hemi engines.
fact8: C-1 taken to ’51 Le Mans in support of BSC’s trio of Hemi-powered, similarly-shaped C-2s.

descr: Serial No. 5224: Chrysler eight-cylinder, hemi-head vee engine, four Zenith downdraft carburetors, 331.1 cubic inches, 220 hp at 4000 rpm.
fact1: LeMans rules dictated BSC build and sell at least 25 cars to be considered a manufacturer (“homologation”).
fact2: C-3 originally meant to be customer version of the C-2, adaptable for street or racing.
fact3: High cost ($15K) of initial C-3s built in West Palm Beach led to decision to out-source bodies from Vignale.
fact4: Vignale-designed body for C-3 patterned after that already designed for Ferrari 212.
fact5: Chassis built in USA, shipped to Italy for body, shipped back to US for final assembly.
fact6: Modified Chrysler “Hemi” V8 - 331 cu. in., 220 HP, 130 mph top speed.
fact7: 20 coupes, 5 convertibles total production of Vignale-body cars.
fact8: A C-3 was in the 1953 MOMA exhibit of the ten best auto designs; Nelson Rockefeller had one & Jay Leno has one.

descr: Serial No. 5216R: Chrysler eight-cylinder, hemi-head vee engine, four Weber 400DCM downdraft carburetors, 331.1 cubic inches, 300 hp at 5200 rpm.
fact1: Significantly better car than the C-2s that ran at LeMans in ‘51.
fact2: 25% lighter, improved brakes & aerodynamics, 300 hp Hemi V-8.
fact3: BSC preferred this car to the more confining C-4RK coupe
fact4: BSC had epic drive in this car in ‘52 LeMans - drove 20 hours to 4th overall despite bad clutch & fading brakes.
fact5: C-4Rs also raced at LeMans in ‘53 (7th overall) & ‘54 (3rd & 5th).
fact6: This car won ‘53 12 Hours of Sebring.
fact7: Later raced successfully in West Coast SCCA races.

descr: Serial No. 5218R: Chrysler eight-cylinder, hemi head vee engine. Four Zenith downdraft carburetors, 331.1 cubic inches
fact1: “K” referred to Dr. Wunibald Kamm, German aerodynamicist who created the “Kamm” back.
fact2: Kamm was one of Von Braun’s rocket scientists, but started as Daimler auto engineer & helped with aerodynamics of BMW 328.
fact3: Kamm personally consulted on the tail design of this coupe.
fact4: Car dropped out of ‘52 LeMans after 8 hr, placed 10th overall in ‘53.
fact5: C-4RK coupe was too confining for BSC, who drove our C-4R roadster.
fact6: Note the enormous fuel filler adjacent to the tiny (but rules-compliant) fire extinguisher.
fact7: This is the only remaining original example.
fact8: It was 3-D scanned in order to build a re-creation which appeared at the 2018 Greenwich Concours d'Elegance.

descr: Serial No. 5319R: Chrysler eight-cylinder, hemi-head vee engine, four Zenith downdraft carburetors, 331.1 cubic inches, 310 hp at 5200 rpm.
fact1: BSC further ups the ante with an even faster car & larger brakes.
fact2: Increased hp, huge 17” truck brakes & solid-front axle (like Indy roadster) to save weight.
fact3: 154 mph top speed & 104 mph race avg. at ‘53 LeMans, but finished 3rd to Jaguar C-Types.
fact4: Jaguars had proprietary use of Dunlop’s new disc brakes; negated C5R’s speed with better cornering.
fact5: Airfoil-shaped body reminiscent of “Le Monstre”; car got airborne & crashed at a 12-hour race in France.
fact6: The French dubbed this “Le Requin” (The Shark) for its shape and toothy grill.

descr: Serial No. B202149: Six cylinder, 60 degree vee engine, two overhead valves per cylinder. 1991 cc, 80 hp at 4700 rpm.
fact1: Lancia’s first post-war car.
fact2: Lancia now run by Vincenzo’s widow Adele & son Gianni.
fact3: Continued Lancia innovation - uni-body, all-independent suspension, transaxle, 1st production V-6.
fact4: Also a capable performer - ‘51 LeMans class win & Mille Miglia 2nd overall.
fact5: Luxury sports car with lots of flair, such as cashmere seats.
fact6: Nearly 3,900 B20s made, produced by Pinin Farina.
fact7: Lancia was the first to fully embrace the new Michelin radial tires which it ran on a B20 at the 1951 LeMans.
fact8: Six series of Aurelias were produced, up until 1957, with increased luxury and power.

descr: Serial No. 550-01: Flat-four, air-cooled, pushrod engine
fact1: First purpose-built mid-engine Porsche race car;
fact2: Car inspired by “specials” homemade from 356s and VWs by VW distributor Walter Glöckler.
fact3: VW-style mechanicals & modified engine, mounted mid-ships on ladder frame. Alloy bodies by Weidenhausen of Frankfurt.
fact4: Revs’ car is serial 001 of four made the first year; total of 89 built.
fact5: 001 won first at the Nürburgring. Ran 2nd IC at LeMans to 002 then sold to Jaroslav Juhan for Carrera Panamericana.
fact6: 001 raced at LeMans, Mexican Carrera Panamericana, Buenos Aires 1,000km and Sebring.
fact7: 001 found in crates in Mexico (2000) with decimated body; aluminum coupe recreated. Body buck 44 is LeMans livery
fact8: 3 of first 4 survive today, REVS has 001, Jerry Seinfeld has 003 and 004 is in the Porsche museum in Stuttgart

descr: Serial No. 1137: Four-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, 1452 cc, 130 hp at 6300 rpm.
fact1: OSCA: “Officine Specializzate Costruzione Automobili” (Office Specialized in Construction Of Automobiles).
fact2: Started by three Maserati brothers, after leaving the company that had already been sold by the family to industrialist Adolfo Orsi.
fact3: Focus was on building a lightweight, small displacement barchetta (“little boat”), open two-seat sports car.
fact4: At under 1,300 lbs, car was able to hit 120 mph with 1.5 liter, 130 hp engine.
fact5: BSC entered this car for ’54 12 Hours of Sebring against more powerful & established opposition.
fact6: Sir Stirling Moss, along with Bill Lloyd, soldiered on while opposition steadily dropped out.
fact7: Moss & Lloyd ended up 1st overall, five laps ahead of the 2nd place; smallest displacement outright win at Sebring.
fact8: In selling these cars at $10,000 ea., OSCA only lasted a decade.

descr: Serial No. 5422R: Current Engine: bored-out 3.8-liter Jaguar D-Type. Original Engine: four-cylinder, in-line Meyer-Drake Offenhauser, 179 cubic inches (2942 cc).
fact1: This is the final car to bear the Cunningham Motor Company name.
fact2: First Cunningham racer to be developed from a full set of engineering plans.
fact3: Design evocative of new D-Type Jaguar.
fact4: Change to 3-liter limit shelved Hemi engines; BSC switched to Offenhauser motor.
fact5: At LeMans the Offy wasn’t able to run on its usual methanol, but low-octane gas; burned valves led to DNF after 19hr.
fact6: C-6R later ran in US with Jaguar 6-cyl. XK engine (still in car).
fact7: With Cunningham Motors losing money five straight years, IRS declares it an “expensive hobby”; BSC ceases car production.

descr: Serial No. XKD507: Six-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, three dual-throat Weber carburetors, 3442 cc (210 cubic inches), 270 hp at 6000 rpm.
fact1: D-type built specifically with Le Mans in mind, with extensive use of aeronautical engineering.
fact2: Aluminum monocoque chassis, XK 6 cyl. engine & disc brakes.
fact3: BSC hedged his bets at LeMans in ‘55 by running this customer car along with his C-6R.
fact4: Factory D-Type won tragedy-marred ‘55 LeMans (84 killed in early race Mercedes crash).
fact5: Cunningham team driver Phil Walters in D-Type retired from race - and racing - after crash.
fact6: Cunningham focused on US racing next three years & became NE US Jaguar distributor.
fact7: This D-Type became ’56 and ’57 SCCA class champ.
fact8: One of few cars in Collier Collections not exercised, as this is last original condition D-Type (of 70 built).

descr: Serial No. Original Transaxle No. D50-0013 Original Engine No. D50A/3: Eight –cylinder, 90⁰ vee engine, double overhead camshafts 2479 cc, 250 hp at 8200 rpm.
fact1: Built by Lancia to the new Post-War GP spec. Develpoment cost bankrupted Lancia racing division.
fact2: Highly innovative: pannier fuel tanks, engine block part of frame, Transaxle and De-Dion suspension
fact3: Mercedes considered this to be their only credible competition in 1954-55
fact4: Cars given to Ferrari in 1955 and were raced for two years.
fact5: Enzo ordered the Lancias destroyed as they weren't real Ferraris (ours is a recreation from original parts)
fact6: Juan Fangio won the drivers championship in 55 in a Mercedes and then again in 56 with a Lancia-Ferrari

descr: Serial No. F2-7-57: Four-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, 1960 cc, 180 bhp at 6500 rpm.
fact1: Brain child of John Cooper, tuner and builder of small racers based on motorcycle engine-trans.
fact2: Mid-engine placement. First post-war application of that design in F1. (Auto Union used pre-war)
fact3: Two liter engine derived from portable fire pumper engine
fact4: Against all odds Sterling Moss wins the Argentine GP in 1958 proving the design strategy
fact5: Cooper would win the constructors championship in 1959 and 1960 and all F1 cars would be mid-engine
fact6: Front and rear suspension derived from Fiat 500 components

descr: Serial No. 1493-06924: Four-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts 1290 cc, 90 hp at 6500 rpm.
fact1: Company’s first “mass volume” model & first new production model in 12 years.
fact2: Fast, comfortable, 'driver friendly', upper middle-class touring car.
fact3: Giulietta originally envisioned as 4-door Berlina & sold lottery chances to drum up interest and raise cash.
fact4: When Berlina faced year of delays, Bertone called in to fast-track the Sprint coupe for the ‘54 Turin auto show.
fact5: Ultimately, the Berlina, Sprint and Spider versions would all sell well, with Sprint a particular success story for Bertone.
fact6: Light unibody construction with high-strung twin-cam engine.
fact7: Veloce means FAST! & was a hopped-up version over standard model.
fact8: Specific designer on this car was a young Giorgio Giugiaro, with typical Italian flair for soft lines.

descr: Serial No. 003: Eight-cylinder 90 degree vee engine, overhead valves, Hilborn fuel injection, 339 cubic inches, 365 hp at 6000 rpm.
fact1: Lance Reventlow - only son of Woolworth heiress Barbara Hutton.
fact2: Hutton’s 4th husband (‘48 Targa winner Igor Troubetzkoy) sparked Lance’s racing interest, $25M trust fund fueled it.
fact3: After limited runs in F2 Coopers, decided to build his own racers to ensure he got the best.
fact4: #003 is one of three sports racers built for WSC; limited to US after WSC rules limit to 3-liters.
fact5: Chevy 339 cu. in. engine, 127 lb. tube frame, De Dion rear w/ quick-change diff. & inboard drum brakes.
fact6: 18-yr old Chuck Pelly designed aluminum body for $200 (later led BMW’s Calf. Studio).
fact7: Scarab sports racers dominated SCCA B-mod in late 50s-early 60s.
fact8: Also built 3 F1 cars - 1st American car/driver since ‘24 & last front-engine in F1 (‘60 Belgian GP).

descr: Serial No. VW5/11: Four-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, fuel injected, 2490 cc, 262 hp at 7500 rpm.
fact1: Last Front engine design to win F1 Constructor championship
fact2: Driven by Sterling Moss and Tony Brooks with great effect
fact3: Aerodynamic design by Frank Costin and chassis by Colin Chapman
fact4: Low drag body was made of Magnesium and the car had Goodyear disc brakes
fact5: Engine based on Norton motorcycle design with Bosh Fuel injection

descr: Serial No. F2-26-59: Four-cylinder in-line engine, twin overhead camshafts, 2495 cc, 239 hp at 6750 rpm.
fact1: First Mid engine car to win F1 constructors championship
fact2: Jack Brabham won the drivers championship with Type 51 in 1959 and 1960
fact3: Ours is one of 3 built for Yeoman Racing for the 1960 season
fact4: Sterling Moss, Dan Gurney and Phil Hill among others successfully raced type 51s
fact5: Cars were more sopisticated with disc brakes and wishbone suspensions

descr: Serial No. 718-007: Flat-four air-cooled engine, mounted midship, twin overhead camshafts 1498 cc, 150 hp at 7200 rpm
fact1: More evolution - simplified rear chassis & wishbone rear suspension instead of swing axles.
fact2: Revs’ car one of two with center steering option, for dual use in Sports & F2 racing (F2 allowed full streamliner bodies for high-speed tracks).
fact3: Absence of paint a weight reduction tactic.
fact4: Steel hood is the primary oil cooler (which was marginally effective),Secondary cooler in drivers side door sill
fact5: Success of factory cars spurred production of 37 for customers.
fact6: 1-2-3-4 finish at ’59 Targa Florio for Porsche. 718 first Overall
fact7: This car raced by the likes of F1 drivers von Trips and Bonnier, campaigned for several years in SCCA road races, & finished as autocrosser.

descr: Serial No. Chassis No. 0120 Engine Nos. AW051-0005/AW051-0008: Twin horizontally-opposed two-cylinder air-cooled engines, 425 ccs, 12 bhp at 5300 rpm.
fact1: French version of a “car for the masses”. Normally Front wheel drive 2cyl engines from 9 to 29hp
fact2: Soft suspension, allowed a farmer to put “all his eggs in one basket” without the risk of breaking them.
fact3: Easily removable doors, & a roll-back roof to accommodate tall objects.
fact4: A popular car for police & Alpine rescue work.
fact5: Designed just prior to outbreak of WWII, 2CV enjoyed a production run of 4 million over 42 years.
fact6: Around 250 of the special Sahara model served for oil exploration in Africa.
fact7: Our Sahara features dual flat-twin engines front and rear for a version of 4-wheel drive.

descr: Serial No. 2468: Four-cylinder in-line engine, dual overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, 1990.2cc, 200 hp at 7800 rpm.
fact1: One of the last of the classic front-engine sports racers.
fact2: Driver/journalist Denise McCluggage dubbed it the “Birdcage”.
fact3: Intricate space frame chassis made of some 200 finger-width tubes - rationale: the more tubes used the thinner they can be.
fact4: Frame weighed less than 70 lbs. but proved too fragile & complex; hard to get to engine.
fact5: Great performance but poor reliability.
fact6: Six T60s & 16 T61s (with 2,890cc engine) built 1959-61.
fact7: A T60 won in its first outing in ’59, and T61s with larger engines won ’60, ’61 Nurburgring 1,000K.
fact8: BSC & Jim Kimberly finished 8th overall (3rd in class) at ‘61 LeMans in this car.

descr: Serial No. 578-1: Eight-cylinder vee-type engine, double overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, 1498 cc, 193 bhp at 10,250 rpm.
fact1: 1962 F1 Champion Constructor (B.R.M.) and Driver (Graham Hill)
fact2: 'Old Faithful' 578 Chassis #1 raced 3 seasons, over 20,000 racing miles.
fact3: Won Spa Grand Prix, Goodwood Grand Prix and 2nd at United States GP
fact4: Slim 'cigar' shape cheats the air but could trap the driver between fuel tanks in a crash
fact5: Steering ratios, wheels and nose altered for different circuits
fact6: B.R.M = British Racing Motors
fact7: In 1962 placed 9th at French GP behind Dan Gurney driving the F1 Porshe 804 to it's only F1 victory
fact8: 1962 recap: 6 1st, 4 2nd, 1 4th, 1 9th, 1 15th, 3 rtd. F1 Champion car and driver

descr: Serial No. Serial Nos. - Chassis 4031SA / 3097SA - Engine 1287A: Twelve-cylinder vee overhead camshaft engine, 3967 cc, 340 bhp at 7000 rpm.
fact1: One of the few Ferraris that Enzo owned & used (he apparently preferred Peugeots).
fact2: Of 46 Superamericas built 1959-64, this was one of 14 short-wheelbase Aerodynamic coupes.
fact3: Top-of-the-line Ferrari for ultra-exclusive clients.
fact4: Each car’s body & interior individually tailored by the Pininfarina (one word now) design house.
fact5: First road-going Ferrari with disc brakes.
fact6: This Colombo-designed 4-liter V-12 engine started life in another (prototype) chassis (SN doesn’t match).
fact7: Verde Dora is the name for the light metallic green color; was also available for Fiats and Maseratis.*
fact8: After his year with car, Enzo had front resprayed, interior changed & serial number  - then sold as new.

descr: Serial No. 860630: Six-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, two valves per cylinder, Lucas fuel injection, 3781 cc (230.6 cubic inches), 300 hp at 6000 rpm.
fact1: Jaguar’s first new sports car after ’56 factory fire.
fact2: Carried on D-Type design elements: monocoque chassis, front subframe, disc brakes, rack & pinion steering.
fact3: Instant auto show sensation - looks, price (£2,000 to start), performance (150 mph).
fact4: Enzo Ferrari grudgingly called E-Type “The most beautiful car ever made”.
fact5: BSC’s last drive at Le Mans was in this car (w/ Roy Salvadori) - 4th overall, 1st in class in 1962.
fact6: While a few lightweight competition E-Types were built, Jaguar never raced a factory car.

descr: Serial No. Serial No. EB 1661: Four-cylinder in-line engine, single overhead camshaft, twin SU carburetors, 1216 cc, 95 bhp at 7200 rpm.
fact1: First production car effort from a company that had previously built only race cars.
fact2: Colin Chapman’s mantra: “Build more lightness” – extremely light weight from plexiglas load-bearing monocoque structure
fact3: Excellent handling from its race car suspension and advanced aerodynamics.
fact4: Climax engine for power to Six Le Mans class victoriesClimax engines were originally designed for fire truck pumper motors.
fact5: Elites raced at Le Mans and claimed six class victories.
fact6: Just over 1,000 units were produced between 1958 and 1963.
fact7: This car restored to “Primrose Yellow” during 2018 restoration, after small patch of original paint discovered under layer of silver repaint.

descr: Serial No. 004: V8 - 377 cubic inches (6.2 liters), 4 dual throat Weber Carburetors
fact1: Ford sidestepped AAMA ban on racing by supplying engines and tech to Carroll Shelby who was busy building Cobras.
fact2: Chevy head Semon 'Bunkie' Knudsen & Zora Duntov defy GM Chairman’s hold to AAMA ban on racing.
fact3: Duntov starts skunkworks operation to build 5 Cobra-beater, heavily-modified Corvettes
fact4: Corvette 'Lightweight', 1,100 lbs. cut from street ‘Vette, with 377 cu. in. Aluminum, 485 hp Chevy engine.
fact5: 3 of the 5 cars issued to trusted teams for ’63 Nassau Speed Week where they dominate Cobras.
fact6: Press hails 'new Corvette race car' GM Chairman finds out & orders program killed.
fact7: Before they could be crushed all sold or hidden. Two modified into roadsters, all survive today
fact8: #004 raced into early 80s; one owner (Delmo Johnson) “raced car 30,000 miles” over 2 yrs.

descr: Serial No. 1360067: Four-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, 1946 cc (119 cubic inches), 204 hp at 7200 rpm.
fact1: Alliance between Simca (France) and 'tuner' Abarth (Italy), to enhance image through competition
fact2: 1964 European hill climb champion
fact3: Highly modified Abarth rear mounted engine tough on transmissions
fact4: Diminutive Steel unibody construction allowed light weight
fact5: Approximately 300 built
fact6: The car’s logo depicts the scorpion, Carlo Abarth’s Zodiac sign.

descr: Serial No. 750052: Four-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, 1570 cc, 175 bhp at 6500 rpm
fact1: The car that returned Alfa to racing after a long post-WWII absence.
fact2: Tubular space frame weighing just over 100 pounds, with aluminum Zagato body using Kamm tail design.
fact3: Highly tuned Conrero DOHC engine developing 175 HP
fact4: Fully independent suspension front and rear
fact5: This car was the 1600 GT Sebring 12 Hours class winner in 1964.
fact6: Company name: Anonima Lombardi Fabbrica Automobil (Lombard Automobile Factory, Public Company); Nicola Romeo’s surname added when he took over company (1915).
fact7: Logo highlights company’s roots in Milan, especially cross of the municipality and serpent that is historic symbol of the city.

descr: Serial No. CA2S7L563020: Four-cylinder in-line overhead valve engine. 1278cc (78 cu. in.). Horsepower: 78 bhp @ 6000 rpm.
fact1: Iconic compact car of the ‘60s.
fact2: Born of the ’56 Suez Canal Crisis, and resulting fuel shortages & high taxes.
fact3: Sir Alec Issigonis designed the car around the passenger compartment, then kept the rest of the car as compact as possible.
fact4: Extremely efficient space utilization with 10’x4’x4’ footprint.
fact5: First production car with transverse engine & stacked gearbox.
fact6: Sharp handling led to adaptations for racing. Our car, the 'Cooper S' model the high performance Mini
fact7: 6.5 million units built in 18 body styles over 42 years.
fact8: Mary Quant named trendsetting ‘60s skirt for car.

descr: Serial No. 6217: Twelve-cylinder 60-degree vee engine, single overhead camshaft 3286 cc, 320 hp at 7500 rpm.
fact1: First Ferrari to use mid-engine design in a sports racer, and last to win LeMans, until 2023.
fact2: Designed to be Homogated as a production car but not enough built. Only 32 produced; few exist today.
fact3: Had to compete in more difficult Prototype class at 1965 Le Mans, yet a 250 LM won with privateer Luigi Chinetti’s North American Racing Team.
fact4: This car won hill climbs, amateur and club events. It also won the Lavant Cup at Goodwood Reunion in 2023.
fact5: Originally had short nose from original Scaglietti design, long nose (by Drogo) added following a racing accident.
fact6: Prancing Horse logo an homage to an Italian WWI aero-ace, set against yellow, a color symbolic to Enzo’s hometown of Maranello.

descr: Serial No. 221877: Flat-four air-cooled pushrod engine, rear-mounted, 1582 cc, 95 hp at 5800 rpm.
fact1: End of a 17-year run of the 356, with over 76,000 sold.
fact2: Drum brakes now replaced by disc brakes.
fact3: 1600cc pushrod engine was largest of the series that started at 1100cc.
fact4: Car’s tendency for oversteer could be exploited with Wishen or “wiping” cornering technique.
fact5: Only car in the Collier Collection that’s a “one-owner” (Mr. Collier’s high school graduation present).
fact6: Custom order with several special features, a gas-fueled cabin heater, limited-slip differential, radio Delete, and Badge delete.

descr: Serial No. 1049: Eight-cylinder 90° vee pushrod engine, four twin-choke Weber carburetors, wet sump lubrication, 4736 cc (289 cubic inches), 390 hp at 7000 rpm.
fact1: Henry Ford II saw buyout of Ferrari as way to have instant racing program.
fact2: When Enzo backed out, Ford vowed revenge where it would hurt him most - Le Mans.
fact3: Known first as Ford GT, development model based on Lola GT Mk6.
fact4: Modified small block 289 cu. in. from Mustang produced 390 hp V-8, similar to a winning Indy engine.
fact5: Initial efforts in ‘64 were dismal; program turned over to Carroll Shelby in early ‘65.
fact6: Our car was Gulf Oil VP Grady Davis' personal car, Race prepared to run in 1967 24 hr of Daytona, finishing 6th

descr: Serial No. P/1031/1047: Eight-cylinder 90 degree vee pushrod engine, two Holley four-choke carburetors 6982 cc, 500 bhp at 6000 rpm
fact1: After taking over the Ford team in 1965 Carroll Shelby & Holman-Moody improved aerodynamics, suspension and engine.
fact2: Switch to a NASCAR-type, Holman-Moody engine: 427 cu.in. (7 liter), 500+ hp V-8.
fact3: GT40 MkIIs saw increased success in ‘66, including 1-2-3 finish at Le Mans.
fact4: A GT40 MkIV won ‘67 Le Mans; an improved privateer MkI car won in ‘68 & ‘69.
fact5: This car retired from ‘67 Le Mans at 18 hours; won Reims 12 hour race, raced thru ‘70.
fact6: Over 100 GT40s were built, with four different versions raced, at cost of over $80M.
fact7: Henry Ford II won the battle of the egos and a Ferrari has not won Le Mans since.
fact8: The 'B' variant was a 2 four barrel carburetor version of the MKII

descr: Serial No. AAR104: Twelve cylinder 60 degree vee engine, twin overhead camshafts 2997 cc (183 cubic inches)
fact1: Won 1967 Belgian GP at Spa averaging 146 mph with top speeds over 190 mph
fact2: Last American driver to win a F1 race with a car of his own construction
fact3: Magnesium skin and Titanium components used to reduce weight for F1 competition
fact4: Derived from Len Terry design for Gurney Indy car
fact5: Car nose and Eagle logo designed by Gurney's father
fact6: Only 2nd American driver/car,team win since 1921 Jimmy Murphy French GP in a Duesenberg.
fact7: 400 HP Weslake engine comissioned by Gurney for his F1 Eagle was smooth and powerful Aubrey Woods design
fact8: At this time AAR stood for Anglo American Racers the Gurney F1 team based in Rye, East Sussex, England

descr: Serial No. 2395315: Four-cylinder in-line engine, pushrods with hemispherical combustion chambers, 982 cc, 112 bhp at 8200 rpm.
fact1: Carlo Abarth's first commercial products were low restriction exhaust systems. Ferrari adopted them as standard for it's cars.
fact2: Moved on to building parts for 'Tuner' versions of Fiat 600.
fact3: In 1966 introduced the Abarth 'radiale' cylinder head for the fiat engine allowing a 1000cc engine to develop over 100 hp.
fact4: The head featured a two valve, hemispherical combustion chamber operated by the stock, in block, pushrod system.
fact5: Our car was campaigned by Alfred S. Consentino who piloted it to 34 victories in 35 races, eventually extending to 51 of 53 wins.
fact6: Consentino formed a racing team and import company FAZA (Fiat Aarth Zagato Allemano) in 1963.
fact7: Abarth parts were attractive to the small racing community but not commercially successful. Abarth's company was acquired by Fiat in 1971
fact8: Consentino collected much Abarth historical data and photos which have been digitized and can now be viewed on the Revs Digital Library.

descr: Serial No. 917-019: Flat-twelve air-cooled engine
fact1: Ultimate step in development of a Porsche to win LeMans - which it did in ’70 & ’71.
fact2: Winning cars both years fielded by Louise Piëch, Ferry’s sister.
fact3: 25 cars rushed to completion in 6 months to satisfy homologation in 1970
fact4: Flat 12 engine produced 600 hp, for top speed on the Mulsanne Straight of 246 mph (record stood until 2010).
fact5: Fastest non-production car in the Collection.
fact6: Engine holds 29 quarts of oil! 7 oil pumps in the engine.
fact7: Of the 43 cars built, this was a more-stable short tail version.
fact8: Last example of un-restored Preservation raced 917.

descr: Serial No. 74004: Four-cylinder in-line engine, four valves per cylinder, turbocharged, dry sump lubrication, 161.5 cubic inches.
fact1: Won the 1975 Indy 500 with Bobby Unser as driver. Rain shortened race to 435 miles
fact2: Designed by Roman Slbodynskj (also Lotus 38 and Jim Clark 1965 indy winner)
fact3: Aluminum monocoque chassis with under tray to manage air under the car
fact4: Large rear wing and adjustible front wing to balance downforce
fact5: Average race speed 149.213 mph

descr: Serial No. A10B04: Four-cylinder in-line engine, double overhead camshafts, 1499 cc (92 cubic inches), turbocharged to 2.5 bar (75 in. hg), 650 hp at 10,500 rpm, carbon fiber composite chassis, six speed transmission.
fact1: Placed 5th in 1988 constructors championship
fact2: Carbon Fiber monocoque chassis construction
fact3: Turbocharged BMW 202 based 1.5 liter engine
fact4: Developed 650 hp at 25 bar (but was capable of more)
fact5: Sophisticated rear wing, large front wing and undertray created downforce for ultimate traction
fact6: Tire widths: 12in front, 16in rear

descr: Serial No. 4260867: Twin-cylinder, two-stroke, 594 cc, 26 bhp, HP to WT Ratio: 52.00
fact1: “Iron Curtain Beetle” - East Germany’s answer to the People’s Car.
fact2: The only car available in a country where there was no competition.
fact3: Two cylinder, 2 cycle engine - fuel of oil & gas belched toxic fumes.
fact4: Body built of “Duraplast”, a kind of plastic-coated fiberboard.
fact5: Gravity feed fuel supply, tank over engine!
fact6: Despite car’s shortcomings, over 3.1 million produced over 26 years.
fact7: The second-youngest car in the Collection - and it looks like it came from the 50s.

descr: Serial No. 022: Twelve-cylinder 60-degree vee engine, 6064cc (370 cu in), 627hp at 7400rpm, double overhead camshafts, four valves per cylinder
fact1: Gordon Murray designed the F1 to be the ultimate supercar of the twentieth century.
fact2: McLaren’s first street car, and the first production car with all-carbon fiber monocoque construction.
fact3: A pure driver’s car, with no power-assist or computer-aids, and a center driving position for optimum visibility and weight distribution.
fact4: Top speed of just over 240 mph.
fact5: Between 1993 to ’98, just over 100 F1s were built — a few prototypes, 64 street-use F1s like this, 5 high-performance Le Mans tribute cars, and the rest race-prepared cars
